qas.question: What can threaten endemic species with extinction?
What are another names for genetic pollution?

answers.text: uncontrolled hybridization, introgression and genetic swamping
either a numerical and/or fitness advantage of an introduced species

qas.question: What are are side-effects of introduction and invasion?
What behavior causes swamping of a gene pool?

answers.text: The abundant species can interbreed with the rare species

qas.question: What can threaten morphological species with extinction?

plausible_answers.text: uncontrolled hybridization, introgression and genetic swamping

qas.question: What is another name for interbreeding?

plausible_answers.text: either a numerical and/or fitness advantage of an introduced species

qas.question: What are side-effects of introduction and pollution?

plausible_answers.text: The abundant species can interbreed with the rare species

qas.question: What behavior causes swamping of a normal adaptation?

context: Endemic species can be threatened with extinction through the process of <a0_0><b5_0>genetic pollution<b5_0/><a0_0/>, i.e. <a1_0><b6_0>uncontrolled hybridization, introgression and genetic swamping<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Genetic pollution leads to homogenization or replacement of local genomes as a result of <a2_0><b7_0>either a numerical and/or fitness advantage of an introduced species<b7_0/><a2_0/>. <a3_0><b8_0>Hybridization and introgression<b8_0/><a3_0/> are side-effects of introduction and invasion. These phenomena can be especially detrimental to rare species that come into contact with more abundant ones. <a4_0><b9_0>The abundant species can interbreed with the rare species<b9_0/><a4_0/>, swamping its gene pool. This problem is not always apparent from morphological (outward appearance) observations alone. Some degree of gene flow is normal adaptation, and not all gene and genotype constellations can be preserved. However, hybridization with or without introgression may, nevertheless, threaten a rare species' existence.
